## After class

âœ… **Practice:**

1. Create a new Quarto document (`.qmd`). Add a title, your name, and today's date in the YAML header
2. Write a short introduction in Markdown â€” use headers, bold, italic, and a bulleted list
3. Add a code chunk that loads a dataset and creates a plot. Try `#| echo: false` to hide the code
4. Use inline code to report a summary statistic in a sentence (e.g., "The mean age was `` `r knitr::inline_expr("mean(data$age)")` ``")
5. Render your document to HTML. Then try PDF (you may need to install `tinytex`)

::: {.callout-note}
## The golden rule of reproducibility

**Never hard-code a number in your text.** If your data changes, your text should update automatically.

Instead of:
> "The mean score was 4.2."

Write:
> "The mean score was `` `r knitr::inline_expr("round(mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE), 1)")` ``."

This way, if you add more data or fix an error, everything stays in sync.
:::

### Useful chunk options

```r
#| label: fig-results
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Mean anxiety scores by condition"
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 5

ggplot(data, aes(x = condition, y = anxiety)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "bar") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = mean_se, geom = "errorbar", width = 0.2)
```
